item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: How about reading X MB of the file, finding a convenient break point, and then splitting it into multiple files? Is there any way we can do that without hitting memory limits?

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Unless I'm mistaken, this patch kills backwards compatibility for:

is_page(1)

is_page('about')

You should move that old code above your parse_str() call, so those still work.

Matching by name/slug of descendants or ancestors would be nice, but at least keep current capabilities implemented.

item.description: Spaces and other characters are perfectly legal in filenames both on and off the web. I don't see why we should leave them out.

item.title: Ticket #3179 (warning in category template function) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
Warning: Invalid argument supplied for foreach() in /home/dolelm/public_html/testblog/wp-includes/template-functions-category.php on line 321

You can get this error when all categories are excluded using the available hook to drop categories.

to fix, cast $categories on line 304 as an array, i.e.: 

		$query = "
			SELECT cat_ID, cat_name, category_nicename, category_description, category_parent, category_count
			FROM $wpdb->categories
			WHERE cat_ID > 0 $exclusions
			ORDER BY $sort_column $sort_order";
		$categories = (array) $wpdb->get_results($query);

D.

item.title: Ticket #3011 (Them-Editor theme file name listing problem) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
Keywords changed

It's caused by the PHP function 'dir'.

The following is noted in the manual for that function: The order in which directory entries are returned by the read method is system-dependent.

The only solution I see would be to sort the list, which would give a fixed list on all machines. I've attached a patch that does that.

Only problem is that it's the filenames that are sorted, which leads to a non-alphabetical list, because file descriptions are shown on screen instead of filenames.

item.title: 3011.diff attached to Ticket #3011
item.dc:creator: Nazgul

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) reopened
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description: Please don't close a ticket that I submitted and am working on after it has been opened for less than 4 hours. Your point is taken as is Ryan's. The problem still exists.

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) closed
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
wontfix:

Closing as WONTFIX.

As Ryan describes, it seems problematic to try and adjust environment settings. The only possibly opportunity I could see is user experience / messaging before running and on failure.

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) updated
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description: Understandable. The ideal thing in this situation would be to determine what the actual number is in terms of memory needed and compare against memory_limit. There seems to be a discrepancy between file size bytes and the number of bytes reported in my "exceeded memory limit" error. If you have any good ideas about that we can do some checking before we try to parse.

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: I think some hosts block memory_limit changes to prevent abuse on shared hosting setups.

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: leflo
item.description:
Scalability: Ok, I changed it a bit, now you only get that query if you really need it (descendent_of, ancestor_of), and parent_of has its own query now. Anyhow, that query isn't expensive (at least for < 500 pages and espacally in contrast to the query for get_pages()), the other option would be to do n queries (n = depth) or do some very tricky SQL substatements (which would kill all MySQL 4 support). (Could it be better to use get_pages() since it is/could be cached?)

Walker Classes: Why? I don't really walk the tree, it's more like zipping through a list.

item.title: mt.php.diff attached to Ticket #3178
item.dc:creator: technosailor

item.title: Ticket #3178 (Import should not fail if file size larger than max php memory) created
item.dc:creator: technosailor
item.description:
MT Importer Breaks if File Size takes too much memory

Proposed solution:
Read X MB of the file finding a convenient break point, import and continue where left off.

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Keywords changed

Either needs-patch or has-patch ;-)

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
$results = $wpdb->get_results("SELECT ID, post_parent FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE post_type = 'page'");

I don't like the scalability implications of this.

Can you not switch the patch to do specific queries for the different request types so as to ensure that the SQL request is bounded small enough?

This may make decendent_of stuff harder to work out - can it use any of the walker classes that exist as well?

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: leflo
item.description:
forgot: for 1277_is_page.diff is_page would be called like is_page('id=3') or is_page('descendent_of=3') or even is_page('id=3&descendent_of=3'), which would OR both queries.

is_page supports: id, child_of, descendent_of, parent_of, ancestor_of.

item.title: Ticket #1277 (Extend is_page() to support child_of and decendent_of) updated
item.dc:creator: leflo
item.description:
Keywords, Milestone changed

My favorit would be the extension of is_page. Please comment on the patches.

item.title: 1277_seperate_functions.diff attached to Ticket #1277
item.dc:creator: leflo
item.description: multiple functions: is_child_of_page, is_decendent_of_page. (backward compatible)

item.title: Ticket #890 (support relative paths for enclosures) updated
item.dc:creator: zamoose
item.description: The patch looks good except for one thing: both relative and absolute server paths are caught by it and (incorrectly) routed to $SERVERHTTP_HOST?, n'est ce pas? The ticket submitter requested that both relative (audio/audio.mp3) and absolute (/audio/audio.mp3) work. Would not the current solution direct both links to ​http://$SERVER_URL/audio/audio.mp3, which is fine for /audio/audio.mp3 but which would be incorrect for anyone with a blog URL in any place other than the root for audio/audio.mp3. If there's no leading slash, oughtn't we just use bloginfo('url') or similar?

item.title: Ticket #3177 ("quoted strings" should work in the search box) created
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
When searching for a quoted string, the words in the quoted string should not be broken up and search for separately.

The attached patch includes support for such searches as:

stuff "other things"

This will find posts that match both "stuff" and "other things".

Check stripslashes() calls, please.

​By request.
